positive.review: EMPIRE is my favorite in the series.  Just the campaign map alone makes it the deepest experience and offers great replayability.
Still my absolute favourite of the Total War series, desperately needs a sequel or at least a proper remaster.

This review is written with Total War players in mind. As such, it will not adress basic gameplay that is inherent in all Total War games, such as turn based production and real time battling, but rather will compare Empire: Total War with other Total War titles.

As a Total War fan, my personal preference goes to this title, Empire. I like most Total War games, but Empire stands out to me. For one, I enjoy the historic time period. For two, it plays the most 'different' from the other titles.

Older titles, such as the first Rome: Total War game and Medieval II, heavily favour an agressive play style, with a lot of chaotic melees. Later games, such as Rome II and Shogun II, lean more towards a balanced stance between agression and response, depending on how superior your battlefield position and force is.

Empire: Total War, in contrast, is a game of patience. Instead of charging into melee, the gameplay entails meticulously positioning lines of infantry and laying down volleys of fire. Mirorring the idea of the age, it is the 'gentleman's edition' of Total War. The Fall of the Samurai expansion to Shogun II comes closest to the Empire style of play, with rifle armed infantry and gatling guns, and keeps the option to go into melee samurai charge mode, but Empire remain the only edition (excluding Napoleon: Total War) to favour a line to line exchange of fire.

Another difference is the naval battles. Granted, later editions in the Total War series incorporate these as well, but Romans or Edo era Japanese boats firing on one another with arrows pale next to the awesome power of a multiple deck ships of the line wailing away at one another. Again, Fall of Samurai introduces ironclad ships that approach this somewhat.

Of course, later titles have more recent, better developed versions of some of the aspects of Empire, and there are some other downsides to Empire. As usual with a Total War title, Creative Assembly has a tendency to leaving things not as smooth as they could have been. Most bugs have been smoothed out after release, as they usually are, but some small problems remain here and there (such as batteries of cannon simply not firing unless directed to do so in a very specific way).

Additionally, while the battles themselves offer some of the most unique Total War battle experiences, the map campaign improves little on previous editions. Not that this is necessary, because the region based resources and capture cities work well for the entire series. However, there is one significant improvement to me here, and that is that the map spans the most territory of any Total War game. Where Rome II limits itself to Europe and North Africa, and Shogun II is set in Japan, Empire scopes the entire Western dominated world of the Elizabethan age: Europe, North America, Africa and the Indies. The later release Napoleon: Total War does not nearly reach the score Empire does, and its campaigns are focused on smaller scale conquest rather than the world theatre of Empire.

As for the research system, it seems that the Empire title marks the start of an overhaul, where the series starts mimicing the more traditional 'tech tree' idea that prevails in many strategy games. This is not a bad thing, but it is an addition that was perhaps not entirely necessary. All the more so because sometimes it seems like a shoehorn to introduce the game's traditional late game obstacle. Every Total War game has some sort of hindering mechanic that makes the game prgressively more difficult as time advances. In Empire, research (which you need to keep up with your modernizing rivals) introduces squalor, which makes for an unhappy populace, which makes you either have to sink money into keeping them happy or have to deal with rebellions.

If you prefer a more agressive slugfest in a game, I would suggest Rome II, Shogun II, or if you don't mind some more antiquated aestethics and graphics, Medieval II.
If you like your games new and crisp, the more recent titles are sure to be your thing as well. If you want a more modern game that still uses line infantry and gun batteries, Shogun II's Fall of the Samurai expansion is your ticket.

But if you want a true, professional standing army of line infantry that knows how to hold under fire as well as deliver it, if you want to be a gentleman general of standing, if you want an 18th century battlefield, then this, my friend, this is the game for you.
Once you get past the learning curve issues of the game nuances, it's an engrossing game that sucks you in for hours at a time.

Empire Total War. Game purchased on release over 15 years ago. 

*2010* Intel Dual Core processor 1 or 2 gb of ram, Hard disk. Took a while to load, naval battles unplayable.
going from Medieval 2 to Empire. Empire was alot more hardware demanding of a game then. Visually fresh, awaited and satisfying graphical upgrade from earlier titles. Back then it was Pure Cinema loading into your first battles.

2018 Base game got upgraded to definitive edition adding all dlc and expansions to base game owners for free.
(same with medieval 2 and Napoleon)

*2025* Game is good, still looks good. It is missing some in depth detail in a few areas, one of them being the family tree aspects you know from other TW games.
Though still a decent campaign set in the 18th century. Somehow the missing in depth details that sometimes are missing from this game, leaves a lot more room for the imagination to take charge and somehow make this game an experience that goes above. The UI and Art style also adds to that. 

The AI is not great, but it leaves something for the imagination.

** EmpireTW requires time and patience, battles can be long. It has the same bugs, and they can be anoying and game breaking, but can be worked around with a bit of strategy. 

Encountered game breaking bugs:

1. Siege battle "lag" 
-Cause: When enemy troops stand on a wall and those walls gets destroyed, the game's AI struggles to recalculate its pathfinding in real time when the physical geometry of the fort walls change. 
-Effect: The game's performance drops dramatically, resulting in severe stuttering, low frame rates and very wicked lag. in some cases down to 1 FPS, 1000+ MS Delay. 
-Fix: Do not destroy walls that have troops standing on them, Use Mortar/howitzer explsoive/carcass shells (search youtube/google)

2. Technology is researched, but can't upgrade building.
-Cause: No idea
-Effect: GG
-Fix: Load previous Save.  (Keep a minimum of 5 save files or more in rotation)

This is no longer the Definitive Edition. That the mobile version of the game would get an update with new content, but not the pc version is astounding. Who would play a Total war game on a phone? This definitive edition is missing content.

The ONLY reason i do not recommend this game is due to a save file corruption issue that seems to occur late into a campaign resulting in the game crashing every time you try to load the save game. Research has yielded that there is no fix for this, the files cannot be repaired, and you can only attempt to minimize chances of this occurring but never truly prevent it. It REALLY sucks to lose a campaign after 150+ turns and 20+ hours of gameplay.

Would i have bought this game if i knew about this issue prior? No. Despite this issue, will i still play? Absolutely! This is a great game! If you are not a fan of line warfare, you may prefer other Total War games but if lining up and shooting at each other tickles your fancy, this is the game for you!

I just will always play knowing that my campaigns may never reach total victory due to the aforementioned issue. I guess you could say the game breaks the 4th wall by killing off your save file after 70-80 (in-game) years since no king or queen has ever ruled longer than that!

16 years and still unoptimized, it's been out for 16 years and they have the audacity to release the multiplayer on beta without declaring intentions to update it later. A game completely abandoned, almost impossible to play in the late game and impossible to play multiplayer for more than 2-5 turns. Concept-wise this Total War game is the superior one, same thing can be said about the size of the playable world (however a serious chunk of the map is unusable and many parts of it serve only as resource exploitation areas). Campaign AI is quite stupid, there will be a bridge next to them leading to the enemy's capital but your armies won't take them for some reason and they will circumvent the ENTIRE CONTINENT just to siege the city no less than 5 turns later. You send your armies after rebels, they defeat them and for some reason walk over to exactly where the rebels were which then exhausts them to the point where they can't return to their city (which usually means you'll immediately face a second rebellion the next turn because there are no armies in the city to keep watch). Rakes are unbelievably useless, I feel like they have an assassination success rate of 1/10. What's funny is that when they fail their missions in YOUR territory, they are executed. Why? Am I not the king? I ordered the mission, who could dare to execute someone enacting my orders in my kingdom? Anyways, the idiocy doesn't end there to my torment; because diplomacy AI is also incredibly stupid. You will have fought an empire off 99% of its territories and become the biggest power of Europe or perhaps even the world, and that idiot will pester you with halfwitted offers like establishing a trade agreement in exchange with your most profitable regions, even though they have no rare resources and can barely defend their current territories from you. This doesn't end until you fully invade them and makes the game feel incredibly unimmersive unfortunately and you have to plan your diplomacy around invading whoever sends you stupid offers the most. There are some nations out there that would've been great to play that you can't play. Battle maps that you can choose are too little and soldiers in simulated battles get tired faster than a couch potato that takes a walk for the first time. I guess your generals also have to bring a couple couches with them to whatever conflict you're sending them to. This game had a fantastic potential, but it didn't receive half the attention that Warhammer did and so it died. People didn't abandon this game on a whim, they had to abandon it because it feels like a permanent cash grab the way the Sega never invested in it or worked to maintain it. I would recommend it, but you can't even do a world conquest in this game anyways because of how many times it crashes so my best advice is to watch gameplay videos of it instead.

The main reason i have Total War: Empire is because it was in a Total War bundle. Every time i try and give this game another chance, i end up incredibly bored and frustrated.

Naval combat is slow, irritating, and unrewarding, and the best advice i can find seems to be 'just have double their ships and click auto resolve'. Army combat consists largely of marching rows of muskets at each other, and whoever has the most wins. I miss sword/spear walls, archers, and cavalry charges. Military upkeep costs can quickly overwhelm you even if you focus on your economy above all else.

The campaign map feels extremely slow while simultaneously rushing you to complete your objectives within a time limit. A bit of a mixed bag at the best of times for a series known more for its strategic battles, but feels particularly bad in Empire.

I really don't have the motivation to try and learn and improve, because i just dont see enough reward on the table. I don't think id lose much by turning most things to automatic, but then what would be the point. This game feels like its more for people who are interested in the historical period specifically, rather than fans of the Total War series.

The main reason i have Total War: Empire is because it was in a Total War bundle. Every time i try and give this game another chance, i end up incredibly bored and frustrated.

Naval combat is slow, irritating, and unrewarding, and the best advice i can find seems to be 'just have double their ships and click auto resolve'. Army combat consists largely of marching rows of muskets at each other, and whoever has the most wins. I miss sword/spear walls, archers, and cavalry charges. Military upkeep costs can quickly overwhelm you even if you focus on your economy above all else.

The campaign map feels extremely slow while simultaneously rushing you to complete your objectives within a time limit. A bit of a mixed bag at the best of times for a series known more for its strategic battles, but feels particularly bad in Empire.

I really don't have the motivation to try and learn and improve, because i just dont see enough reward on the table. I don't think id lose much by turning most things to automatic, but then what would be the point. This game feels like its more for people who are interested in the historical period specifically, rather than fans of the Total War series.

The ONLY reason i do not recommend this game is due to a save file corruption issue that seems to occur late into a campaign resulting in the game crashing every time you try to load the save game. Research has yielded that there is no fix for this, the files cannot be repaired, and you can only attempt to minimize chances of this occurring but never truly prevent it. It REALLY sucks to lose a campaign after 150+ turns and 20+ hours of gameplay.

Would i have bought this game if i knew about this issue prior? No. Despite this issue, will i still play? Absolutely! This is a great game! If you are not a fan of line warfare, you may prefer other Total War games but if lining up and shooting at each other tickles your fancy, this is the game for you!

I just will always play knowing that my campaigns may never reach total victory due to the aforementioned issue. I guess you could say the game breaks the 4th wall by killing off your save file after 70-80 (in-game) years since no king or queen has ever ruled longer than that!

Misleading marketing here - this is NOT the "Definitive Edition" of EMPIRE.

The Creative Assembly chose to misdirect its users for reasons unknown.

16 years and still unoptimized, it's been out for 16 years and they have the audacity to release the multiplayer on beta without declaring intentions to update it later. A game completely abandoned, almost impossible to play in the late game and impossible to play multiplayer for more than 2-5 turns. Concept-wise this Total War game is the superior one, same thing can be said about the size of the playable world (however a serious chunk of the map is unusable and many parts of it serve only as resource exploitation areas). Campaign AI is quite stupid, there will be a bridge next to them leading to the enemy's capital but your armies won't take them for some reason and they will circumvent the ENTIRE CONTINENT just to siege the city no less than 5 turns later. You send your armies after rebels, they defeat them and for some reason walk over to exactly where the rebels were which then exhausts them to the point where they can't return to their city (which usually means you'll immediately face a second rebellion the next turn because there are no armies in the city to keep watch). Rakes are unbelievably useless, I feel like they have an assassination success rate of 1/10. What's funny is that when they fail their missions in YOUR territory, they are executed. Why? Am I not the king? I ordered the mission, who could dare to execute someone enacting my orders in my kingdom? Anyways, the idiocy doesn't end there to my torment; because diplomacy AI is also incredibly stupid. You will have fought an empire off 99% of its territories and become the biggest power of Europe or perhaps even the world, and that idiot will pester you with halfwitted offers like establishing a trade agreement in exchange with your most profitable regions, even though they have no rare resources and can barely defend their current territories from you. This doesn't end until you fully invade them and makes the game feel incredibly unimmersive unfortunately and you have to plan your diplomacy around invading whoever sends you stupid offers the most. There are some nations out there that would've been great to play that you can't play. Battle maps that you can choose are too little and soldiers in simulated battles get tired faster than a couch potato that takes a walk for the first time. I guess your generals also have to bring a couple couches with them to whatever conflict you're sending them to. This game had a fantastic potential, but it didn't receive half the attention that Warhammer did and so it died. People didn't abandon this game on a whim, they had to abandon it because it feels like a permanent cash grab the way the Sega never invested in it or worked to maintain it. I would recommend it, but you can't even do a world conquest in this game anyways because of how many times it crashes so my best advice is to watch gameplay videos of it instead.
